Nonlinear dynamics¶

Spin down¶

Functions used for nonlinear dynamics calculations. This

lib.NLD_Functions.Attractor_Plot(file_name, elev=15.0, azim=150, return_vals=False, save_fig=False, close=False)[source]¶

Plots the attractor associated with the data in file_name, essentially the same as Embed_Seymour_Lorimer but with additions. This function should be used in creating publication images then we can change the embedding if required.

Parameters:
  • elev (float) – view elevation
  • azim (float) – view azimuth
Returns:

A 3D plot of the attractor
lib.NLD_Functions.Embed_Seymour_Lorimer(time, x, n=False, frac=8, plot=False)[source]¶

Takes 1d signal x and produces a 3-dimensional embedding calculating the delay integer using the method of Seymour and Lorimer 2010.

Parameters:
  • x (list) – 1D signal to embed
  • time (list) – List of times at which x is sampled or the sampling time
  • n (int) – Specifies the number of delay times to search over, largest delay is given by \(n imes dt\) where \(dt\) is the uniform sampling rate
  • frac (int) – The fraction of data between 0 and the first minimum to be used in fitting a polynomial
  • plot – If true this will return two subplots showing the estimation of delay time :math:` au` and the embedding
Returns:

Embedded data
Return type:

Three lists
lib.NLD_Functions.Torque_over_Io(omega, epsA, chi, anom_torque=True, c=30000000000.0, R=1000000.0)[source]¶

Computes the Goldreich torque for omega=[w1,w2,w3] and magnetic dipole at an angle of chi to the z axis

Parameters:
  • omega (list) – Spin vector in cartesian coordinates
  • epsA (float) – Magnetic deformations
  • chi (float) – Angle between magnetic dipole and the z axis in radians
  • anom_torque (bool) – Whether to include the anomalous torque or not
  • c (float) – Speed of light in CGS default is \(c=3 imes 10^{10}\) cm/s
  • R (float) – Neutron star radius default value \(R=1 imes 10^{6}\) cm
lib.NLD_Functions.Dotted_Variable_Triaxial(file_name, anom_torque=None)[source]¶

Produces \(\dot{\omega}\) from file_name

Parameters:
  • file_name (str) –
  • anom_torque (bool) – Overides the anom_torque flag defined in the file name
Returns:

Time of each measurement and value of \(\dot{\omega}\)
Return type:

(list,list)

Note

The equation to calculate the spin down is given by:
\[\dot{\omega}(t) = \frac{1}{\omega}\left[ \frac{\boldsymbol{T} \cdot \boldsymbol{\omega}}{I_{0}} - \frac{\epsilon_{I1} \omega_{x}T_{x}}{I_{0}(1+\epsilon_{I1})} - \frac{\epsilon_{I3} \omega_{z}T_{z}}{I_{0}(1+\epsilon_{I3})}+ \omega_{x}\omega_{y} \omega_{z} \epsilon_{I1}\epsilon_{I3} \frac{\epsilon_{I3} - \epsilon_{I1}}{(1+\epsilon_{I1}) (1+\epsilon_{I3})}\right]\]
lib.NLD_Functions.Correlation_Sum2(x, y, z, R_min, R_max, number, ith=None, plot=True, verbose=True, save_fig=False, Theiler_window=None)¶

Finds the correlation sum of an attractor in 3D

Parameters:
  • time (list) –
  • x,y,z – Attractor data
  • lnR_min (float) – Natural log of the radius of the smallest test sphere
  • R_max (float) – Natural log of the radius of the largest test sphere
  • ith (int) – reduce the number of points by a factor of ith. This is implemented as x = x[0:len(x):ith]
  • plot (true) – If true this plots ln(C) against ln(R) showing how the correlation dimension is calculated
  • Theiler_window (int) – Option to use the Thieler window
..note:: If you are unfamiliar with how this correlation dimension is
calculated please refer to equation (10) from Seymour and Lorimer. The Thieler window is not used.
